citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
On 01APR2025 an older lioness (Isabella), and older lion (Jabri), and a black African leopard (Onyx) were observed with
decreased muscle mass with hips, ribs, and spine prominently displayed under the skin. These animals have not been
evaluated or treated by the attending veterinarian to diagnose any dietary insufficiency, diseases, or injuries accounting
for the loss of body condition. At the time of this inspection the Attending Veterinarian (AV) advised he had not been
consulted or requested by the facility to examine or treat these animals since the last routine inspection on 03DEC2024.
Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of
appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.

A portion of the perimeter fence failed to meet the minimum height requirement for a facility with potentially dangerous
animals, without written approval by the Administrator. Approximately 50 feet of 8-foot-tall hedge row was cleared from
the north side of the facility revealing a 5-foot-tall chain-link fence representing this portion of the perimeter fence. An
incomplete perimeter fence could allow unauthorized people and animals to access the zoo animals and cause harm.
Also, if an animal escaped its primary enclosure, it could leave the zoo and be injured or pose danger to the general
public. The facility must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is sufficient to keep animals and unauthorized persons out
so that it protects the animals as well as function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility.

During inspection two metal trash cans used to store the pelleted and whole grain diet fed to facility hoof-stock were found
with one of the cans without a lid but both containers had contents contaminated with multiple dried rodent droppings.
Feeding animals food contaminated with rodent feces affects animal wellbeing by transmitting pathogen that may result in
disease or death. Food shall be wholesome palatable and free from contamination in order to protect the welfare of the
animals from pathogens carried by feces from vermin. Correct by feeding animals food that is free of contaminants as well
as providing adequate measures to prevent contamination of the food.

At the time of inspection, the facility remains with an inadequate program of pest control with regards to rodents. At
inspection, live rats and their fecal material were seen on structures within the hoof-stock feed storage shed including on
furniture, the floor, rafters and framing of walls and ceiling. A significant number of rodent fecal droppings surrounded the
commercially formulated nonhuman primate (NPH) food storage bins including but not limited to the middle of the floor, in
corners, and on empty bags in the NPH storage shed. Rodents and other pests harm animal welfare by harboring
diseases and parasites that can be transmitted to vulnerable zoo animals. A safe and effective program for the control of
insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests must be established and maintained.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
GWENDALYN MAGINNIS, Nonhuman Primate Field Specialist n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
On 01APR2025 an older lioness (Isabella), and older lion (Jabri), and a black African leopard (Onyx) were observed with 
decreased muscle mass with hips, ribs, and spine prominently displayed under the skin. These animals have not been 
evaluated or treated by the attending veterinarian to diagnose any dietary insufficiency, diseases, or injuries accounting 
for the loss of body condition. At the time of this inspection the Attending Veterinarian (AV) advised he had not been 
consulted or requested by the facility to examine or treat these animals since the last routine inspection on 03DEC2024. 
Each dealer or exhibitor shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of 
appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. 
3.127(d)  Repeat
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
A portion of the perimeter fence failed to meet the minimum height requirement for a facility with potentially dangerous 
animals, without written approval by the Administrator. Approximately 50 feet of 8-foot-tall hedge row was cleared from 
the north side of the facility revealing a 5-foot-tall chain-link fence representing this portion of the perimeter fence. An 
incomplete perimeter fence could allow unauthorized people and animals to access the zoo animals and cause harm. 
Also, if an animal escaped its primary enclosure, it could leave the zoo and be injured or pose danger to the general 
public. The facility must be enclosed by a perimeter fence that is sufficient to keep animals and unauthorized persons out 
so that it protects the animals as well as function as a secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. 
3.129(a)  Direct Repeat
   
Feeding. 
During inspection two metal trash cans used to store the pelleted and whole grain diet fed to facility hoof-stock were found 
with one of the cans without a lid but both containers had contents contaminated with multiple dried rodent droppings. 
Feeding animals food contaminated with rodent feces affects animal wellbeing by transmitting pathogen that may result in 
disease or death. Food shall be wholesome palatable and free from contamination in order to protect the welfare of the 
animals from pathogens carried by feces from vermin. Correct by feeding animals food that is free of contaminants as well 
as providing adequate measures to prevent contamination of the food. 
3.131(d)  Repeat

Sanitation. 
At the time of inspection, the facility remains with an inadequate program of pest control with regards to rodents. At 
inspection, live rats and their fecal material were seen on structures within the hoof-stock feed storage shed including on 
furniture, the floor, rafters and framing of walls and ceiling. A significant number of rodent fecal droppings surrounded the 
commercially formulated nonhuman primate (NPH) food storage bins including but not limited to the middle of the floor, in 
corners, and on empty bags in the NPH storage shed. Rodents and other pests harm animal welfare by harboring 
diseases and parasites that can be transmitted to vulnerable zoo animals. A safe and effective program for the control of 
insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests must be established and maintained. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
GWENDALYN MAGINNIS, Nonhuman Primate Field Specialist n
